questions.text: A young woman with type 1 diabetes presents to the emergency department with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) after stopping insulin. On examination, she is delirious and initial laboratory reports show: S. Na 128 mEq/L, S. K+ 4.3 mEq/L, BUN 76 mg/dL, S. Cr 2.2 mg/dL, S. HCO3- 10 mEq/L, Blood glucose 520 mg/dL. Which of the following is NOT an appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 3% NaCl

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. 0.9% sodium chloride (NaCl): This isotonic fluid is appropriate for rehydration in DKA.
  • • Option B. 0.9% sodium chloride (NaCl):
  • • Option C. Insulin infusion: This is essential to lower blood glucose levels and correct ketoacidosis in DKA.
  • • Option C. Insulin infusion:
  • • Option D. Potassium supplementation: While initial potassium levels are normal, they can drop rapidly with insulin therapy. Therefore, potassium supplementation is often necessary during DKA treatment.
  • • Option D. Potassium supplementation:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypertonic saline (3% NaCl) is not indicated in DKA with pseudohyponatremia; it could worsen the hyperosmolar state.

  • • Option D. Scleredema:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diabetic dermopathy, characterized by hyperpigmented atrophic macules over the shins, is the most common cutaneous manifestation of diabetes.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) has a negative urine microalbumin test. When should the next urine microalbumin test be repeated?
questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • Option D. In 5 years:

  • ➤ Annual screening for microalbuminuria is recommended in type 2 diabetes to detect early signs of diabetic nephropathy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with type 2 diabetes presents to the emergency department with DKA. His initial blood glucose level is 650 mg/dL. After 6 hours of treatment with intravenous fluids and insulin, his blood glucose drops to 200 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Add dextrose to the intravenous fluids

options.label: D
options.text: Increase the rate of the insulin infusion

questions.correct_answer: C. Add dextrose to the intravenous fluids
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Add dextrose to the intravenous fluids

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Discontinue the insulin infusion: Insulin should not be discontinued until the ketoacidosis is resolved, as indicated by a normal anion gap and beta-hydroxybutyrate level.
  • • Option A. Discontinue the insulin infusion:
  • • Option B. Switch to subcutaneous insulin: Subcutaneous insulin is not appropriate in the acute management of DKA.
  • • Option B. Switch to subcutaneous insulin:
  • • Option D. Increase the rate of the insulin infusion: Increasing the insulin infusion rate could lead to hypoglycemia.
  • • Option D. Increase the rate of the insulin infusion:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When blood glucose drops to 200-250 mg/dL during DKA treatment, add dextrose to IV fluids to prevent hypoglycemia and continue insulin infusion.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy with type 1 diabetes presents with vomiting, abdominal pain, lethargy, and drowsiness. His blood glucose is 350 mg/dL, and ABG shows the following – pH 7.24, S. Na 130 mEq/L, S. K 3.0 mEq/L, S. HCO3- 14 mEq/L, and S. Cl 88 mEq/L. His BP is 90/60 mm Hg, and IV fluids were rushed. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IV KCl

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. IV Aspart: Insulin therapy is essential in DKA but should be started after correcting hypokalemia. Regular insulin is preferred for IV use in view of lesser cost but rapid acting analogs can also be used for IV use and are not contraindicated.
  • • Option A. IV Aspart:
  • • Option C. IV NaHCO3: Sodium bicarbonate is generally not recommended in DKA unless the pH is less than 6.9 or there are significant cardiac complications.
  • • Option C. IV NaHCO3:
  • • Option D. CT head: Cerebral edema is a rare complication of DKA and usually occurs in children during treatment. It is not the immediate priority in this scenario.
  • • Option D. CT head:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Administer IV potassium chloride to correct hypokalemia before initiating insulin therapy in DKA to prevent severe hypokalemia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with recurrent hypoglycemia, confirmed by Whipple's triad. Laboratory investigations reveal a beta-hydroxybutyrate (β-OHB) level of 5 mmol/L and a poor blood glucose response to glucagon. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Non-insulin-mediated hypoglycemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Insulinoma: This would typically present with suppressed ketone levels due to the inhibitory effect of excess insulin on lipolysis and ketogenesis.
  • • Option A. Insulinoma:
  • • Option B. Factitious hypoglycemia due to sulfonylurea: Sulfonylureas increase insulin secretion, and hypoglycemia due to these medications would and tend to have suppressed β-OHB (< 2.7 mmol/L) in view of hyperinsulinemia.
  • • Option B. Factitious hypoglycemia due to sulfonylurea:
  • • Option D. IGF-2 related hypoglycemia: This is a rare cause of hypoglycemia and tend to have suppressed β-OHB (< 2.7 mmol/L) in view of insulin like action.
  • • Option D. IGF-2 related hypoglycemia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Elevated β-OHB levels and poor response to glucagon indicate non-insulin-mediated hypoglycemia, such as critical illness or organ failure.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with dizziness. On examination, his BP is 180/110 mm Hg, and he has stretch marks in the trunk. His blood reports show a serum potassium (S. Potassium) of 2.7 mEq/L and HCO3- of 31 mEq/L. He also has elevated aldosterone levels, and after a dexamethasone suppression test, his serum cortisol was 60 nmol/L. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Connshing syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cushing's syndrome: Even though patient has features of Cushing’s syndrome, he also has elevated aldosterone, hence it is not the accurate diagnosis.
  • • Option A. Cushing's syndrome:
  • • Option B. Conn’s syndrome : Even though patient has features of Conn’s syndrome, he also has elevated cortisol, hence it is not the accurate diagnosis.
  • • Option B.
  • • Conn’s syndrome
  • • Option C. Liddle's syndrome: This is a rare genetic disorder causing similar electrolyte abnormalities but with normal or low aldosterone levels.
  • • Option C. Liddle's syndrome:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of features indicating both Conn's syndrome (mineralocorticoid excess with hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis) and Cushing's syndrome (elevated cortisol levels after dexamethasone suppression) points towards Connshing syndrome, where both aldosterone and cortisol are elevated.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the clinic reporting ankle swelling. On examination, his blood pressure is elevated at 162/86, and he has bilateral ankle edema. Laboratory studies show a potassium of 2.9 and normal creatinine. Which of the following studies is recommended next?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Plasma renin and aldosterone

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Dexamethasone suppression: This test is used to diagnose Cushing's syndrome (excess cortisol production). While Cushing's syndrome can cause hypertension, it is not typically associated with hypokalemia and edema.
  • • Option A. Dexamethasone suppression:
  • • Option B. CT of adrenals: This imaging study can be useful to identify adrenal tumors, but it should be performed after biochemical confirmation of hyperaldosteronism.
  • • Option B. CT of adrenals:
  • • Option D. Urine metanephrines: This test is used to diagnose pheochromocytoma, a tumor that produces catecholamines. While pheochromocytoma can cause hypertension, it is not typically associated with hypokalemia and edema.
  • • Option D. Urine metanephrines:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The patient's presentation (hypertension, hypokalemia, and edema) suggests hyperaldosteronism. The initial test should be measuring plasma renin and aldosterone levels to confirm the diagnosis and determine if the cause is primary (adrenal) or secondary.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with resistant hypertension and a serum potassium level of 2.9 mEq/L, with normal creatinine. Which of the antihypertensives need not be stopped prior to the test you are about to perform to screen for the disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Prazosin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Propranolol (beta-blocker): Can lower plasma renin activity (PRA), potentially masking primary aldosteronism (false positive test). It should be stopped 2 weeks before the test.
  • • Option B. Propranolol (beta-blocker):
  • • Option C. Spironolactone (mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist): Directly affects aldosterone levels (false positive test). and should be stopped 4 weeks before the test.
  • • Option C. Spironolactone (mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist):
  • • Option D. Enalapril (ACE inhibitor): Can increase plasma renin activity, potentially leading to a false-negative result. It should be stopped 2 weeks before the test.
  • • Option D. Enalapril (ACE inhibitor):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Prazosin (an α-1 blocker) does not significantly affect the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) and can be continued during testing for primary aldosteronism. Other medications like beta-blockers, mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists, and ACE inhibitors should be stopped prior to testing.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man with episodic, severe hypertension is referred with mild depression and current medications including sertraline, atenolol, amlodipine, and enalapril. Urine 24-hour total metanephrines show a borderline (1.5x) elevation. What is the next most appropriate step?

options.label: A
options.text: Hold atenolol for 1 week and repeat testing

options.label: B
options.text: Hold sertraline for 1 week and repeat testing

options.label: D
options.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.correct_answer: A. Hold atenolol for 1 week and repeat testing
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hold atenolol for 1 week and repeat testing

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Hold sertraline for 1 week and repeat testing: Sertraline is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor, not a TCA. Hence its unlikely to affect the test.
  • • Option B. Hold sertraline for 1 week and repeat testing:
  • • Option C. Start α-blockers and then β-blockers: This may be the initial management of pheochromocytoma, once the diagnosis is established, but NOT appropriate in this case with borderline metanephrine elevations.
  • • Option C. Start α-blockers and then β-blockers:
  • • Option D. CT of the abdomen and pelvis: This may be done to localize pheochromocytoma, once biochemical diagnosis is established.
  • • Option D. CT of the abdomen and pelvis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Borderline elevated metanephrines can be influenced by certain medications, including beta-blockers like atenolol. The next step is to stop potentially interfering medications and repeat the test to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common mutation found in ACTH-secreting pituitary adenomas?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) USP8

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. PRKAR1A: Mutations in this gene are associated with Carney complex, which is usually associated with PPNAD (Primary pigmented Nodular Adrenal Disease).
  • • Option A. PRKAR1A:
  • • Option C. GNAS1: Activating mutations in this gene can result in McCune-Albright syndrome (MAS). Cushing’s syndrome in MAS is usually ACTH independent.
  • • Option C. GNAS1:
  • • Option D. PRKACA: Mutations in this gene are found in a subset (40%) of cortisol-producing adrenal adenomas and are not typically associated with ACTH-secreting pituitary adenomas.
  • • Option D. PRKACA:
  • • Another mutation in a tumor suppressor gene ARMC5 have been identified as a prevalent cause of Cushing’s due to bilateral macronodular adrenal hyperplasia.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ USP8 mutations are the most frequent genetic alterations found in ACTH-secreting pituitary adenomas, leading to increased deubiquitination and stabilization of the EGFR, which promotes ACTH synthesis and secretion.

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard to differentiate Cushing's disease (ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma) from ectopic Cushing's syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inferior petrosal sinus sampling.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. High dose Dexamethasone suppression test: While this test can help distinguish between different causes of Cushing's syndrome, it is not as specific as IPSS in differentiating pituitary from ectopic ACTH secretion.
  • • Option B. High dose Dexamethasone suppression test:
  • • Cortisol suppression >50% after q6h 2 mg DEX for 2 days is suggestive of Cushing’s disease.
  • • Cortisol suppression >50% after q6h 2 mg DEX for 2 days is suggestive of Cushing’s disease.
  • • Option C. CRH stimulation test: This test can be helpful in the evaluation of Cushing's syndrome, but it is not the gold standard for differentiating between pituitary and ectopic sources of ACTH.
  • • Option C. CRH stimulation test:
  • • ACTH increase >40% at 15–30 min + cortisol increase >20% at 45–60 min after CRH 100 μg IV is suggestive of Cushing’s disease.
  • • ACTH increase >40% at 15–30 min + cortisol increase >20% at 45–60 min after CRH 100 μg IV is suggestive of Cushing’s disease.
  • • Option D. MRI of the pituitary: MRI can detect pituitary tumors, but not all ACTH-producing tumors are visible on MRI. Additionally, incidental pituitary lesions can be found in patients without Cushing's disease.
  • • Option D. MRI of the pituitary:
  • • In the presence of cortisol & ACTH excess, a lesion > 6 mm is suggestive of Cushing’s disease.
  • • In the presence of cortisol & ACTH excess, a lesion > 6 mm is suggestive of Cushing’s disease.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inferior petrosal sinus sampling (IPSS) is the gold standard for differentiating Cushing's disease from ectopic ACTH syndrome by measuring ACTH levels from the inferior petrosal sinuses and comparing them with peripheral levels after CRH administration.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman with resistant hypertension and muscle weakness has a serum potassium of 2.8 mEq/L. Her plasma renin activity (PRA) is very low and her aldosterone levels are elevated. What is the most common cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Unilateral adrenal adenoma: While a common cause of primary aldosteronism, it is less frequent than bilateral adrenal hyperplasia.
  • • Option B. Unilateral adrenal adenoma:
  • • Option C. Adrenocortical carcinoma: This is a rare cause of primary aldosteronism.
  • • Option C. Adrenocortical carcinoma:
  • • Option D. Pheochromocytoma: This is a tumor of the adrenal medulla that secretes catecholamines. It is not associated with the typical findings of primary aldosteronism.
  • • Option D. Pheochromocytoma:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia is the most common cause of primary aldosteronism, accounting for 60-70% of cases. It leads to elevated aldosterone and low plasma renin activity, causing hypertension and hypokalemia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with severe hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. His brother died of intracranial hemorrhage (ICH) at the age of 12. His plasma renin and aldosterone levels are low, and his blood pressure normalized after adding spironolactone. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Apparent mineralocorticoid excess (SAME)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Liddle syndrome: Response to spironolactone would be poor. Patients typically respond to amiloride (as this disorder is due to hyperfunctioning ENaC channels in the principal cells).
  • • Option A. Liddle syndrome:
  • • Option B. Gordon syndrome (PHA2): Response to spironolactone would be poor and patients usually present with hypertension, hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis. Patients typically respond to thiazides (as this disorder is due to hyperfunctioning Na-Cl transporters in the DCT).
  • • Option B. Gordon syndrome (PHA2):
  • • Option C. Gitelman syndrome: This syndrome can cause hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis, but patients tend to be normotensive and renin/aldosterone levels would be elevated.
  • • Option C. Gitelman syndrome:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ SAME is caused by a deficiency of 11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase type 2, leading to cortisol acting as a potent mineralocorticoid. The patient's response to spironolactone supports this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with resistant hypertension> His serum potassium is 3 mEq/L, and his serum HCO3- is 29 mEq/L. His renin levels were low and aldosterone levels were elevated. What is the confirmatory test for the suspected diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Saline infusion test

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Dexamethasone suppression test: This test is used to diagnose Cushing's syndrome (excess cortisol production), not primary aldosteronism.
  • • Option A. Dexamethasone suppression test:
  • • Option C. CT scan of the abdomen: This imaging test can help visualize adrenal glands and identify tumors, but it does not confirm the functional diagnosis of primary aldosteronism.
  • • Option C. CT scan of the abdomen:
  • • Option D. Urinary metanephrines: This test is used to diagnose pheochromocytoma, which is not consistent with the patient's presentation.
  • • Option D. Urinary metanephrines:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The saline infusion test is the confirmatory test for primary aldosteronism. It involves administering saline and measuring aldosterone levels, which should suppress if primary aldosteronism is present.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with an incidental 6 cm adrenal lesion with a radiodensity of 45 HU. Which of the following is NOT predictive of adrenocortical cancer (ACC)?
questions.correct_answer: D. Calcifications in the adrenal gland
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Calcifications in adrenal gland

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Radiodensity > 20 HU: Adrenocortical carcinomas typically have higher radiodensity on unenhanced CT scans (>20 HU) due to their lower fat content.
  • • Option A. Radiodensity > 20 HU:
  • • Option B. Size ≥ 4 cm: Larger adrenal lesions are more likely to be malignant. A 6 cm lesion is highly suspicious for ACC.
  • • Option B. Size ≥ 4 cm:
  • • Option C. Elevated steroid precursors in urine: Adrenocortical carcinomas often produce excess steroid precursors, which can be detected in urine. This is a suggestive feature of malignancy.
  • • Option C. Elevated steroid precursors in urine:
  • • A recently introduced diagnostic test, urine steroid metabolomics, has a 2x higher PPV than imaging in detecting ACC, based on a distinct “steroid fingerprint” with accumulating precursor steroids in 24-h urine.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Calcifications can be present in adrenal lesions but are more commonly associated with benign lesions like adrenal adenomas and do not necessarily predict malignancy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain, fever and vomiting. She takes insulin for type 1 diabetes. On examination, her mucosa is dry and the appearance is shown in the image. You order an ABG and the results are as follows - pH – 7.29, Na – 129 mEq/L, K – 5.6 mEq/L, HCO3- 18 mEq/L, Cl – 101 mEq/L and her RBS is 89 mg/dL. Her ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Her BP is 80/40 mm Hg and her PR is 122/min. You give an IV fluid bolus and her BP slightly improves. What is the most important treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Give hydrocortisone 100mg IV.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Start IV insulin infusion: While the patient has type 1 diabetes, her current blood glucose is within the normal range, and insulin infusion is not the priority in this emergency situation.
  • • Option B. Start IV insulin infusion:
  • • Option C. Start IV NaHCO3: Correcting acidosis is important, but the primary concern is addressing the underlying adrenal insufficiency with hydrocortisone.
  • • Option C. Start IV NaHCO3:
  • • Option D. Start IV Insulin + Dextrose: This is an initial therapy in hyperkalemia, to transiently lower serum potassium levels. But in adrenal crisis, correction of underlying cause is important by administering hydrocortisone.
  • • Option D. Start IV Insulin + Dextrose:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The patient's presentation is strongly suggestive of an adrenal crisis. Administering intravenous hydrocortisone is the most important treatment to replace the deficient cortisol.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy with known Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) presents with bilateral testicular masses. His serum ACTH levels are elevated, and ultrasound reveals B/L hypoechoic lesions in the testes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate surgical removal of the testicular masses

options.label: D
options.text: Perform a biopsy of the testicular masses to rule out malignancy

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Start high-dose glucocorticoid therapy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Immediate surgical removal of the testicular masses: Surgery is not the initial approach for adrenal rest tumors. Medical management with glucocorticoids is usually attempted first.
  • • Option A. Immediate surgical removal of the testicular masses:
  • • Option C. Initiate testosterone replacement therapy: Testosterone replacement is not indicated for adrenal rest tumors and may even worsen the condition by stimulating further tumor growth.
  • • Option C. Initiate testosterone replacement therapy:
  • • Option D. Perform a biopsy of the testicular masses to rule out malignancy: While biopsy can be considered in cases with atypical features or lack of response to glucocorticoids, it is not the most appropriate initial step. Adrenal rest tumors are typically benign, and the clinical presentation and imaging findings strongly suggest this diagnosis.
  • • Option D. Perform a biopsy of the testicular masses to rule out malignancy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bilateral testicular masses in a patient with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) are likely due to testicular adrenal rest tumors (TART). High-dose glucocorticoid therapy suppresses ACTH production and induces regression of the tumors.

questions.text: Screening for Parathyroid disorder in MEN 1 should begin at the age of?

Ans. B) 8 years

questions.text: A couple comes for counseling regarding their newborn's health. The father of the child had an MTC, was operated on recently, and was known to have a RET codon 918 mutation. The newborn has been screened and carries the same mutation as well. What will be your advice regarding the newborn?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Immediate total thyroidectomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. S. Calcium at 11 years: Recommended for RET codon 634 or 883 mutations, where hyperparathyroidism is common. Hyperparathyroidism is not a feature of codon 918 mutations, hence screening is NOT recommended. For mutations other than For 663, 883 and 918 – screening can be started at 16 years.
  • • Option A. S. Calcium at 11 years:
  • • Option C. Plasma metanephrines at 16 years: Recommended for screening of pheochromocytoma for RET codon mutations (other than 663, 883 and 918). For 663, 883 and 918 mutations – screening should be started at 11 years.
  • • Option C. Plasma metanephrines at 16 years:
  • • Option D. MRI pituitary at 5 years: This is the recommendations for screening pituitary tumors in case of MEN1. Pituitary tumors are not associated with MEN2B.
  • • Option D. MRI pituitary at 5 years:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Immediate total thyroidectomy is recommended for newborns with RET codon 918 mutation to prevent medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC).
